channel.title: About me on Jan-Pieter D'Anvers
channel.description: Recent content in About me on Jan-Pieter D'Anvers

item.title: Other projects
item.description: Engineering and science communications have always been passions of mine. However, I’m always looking forward to broaden my horizon with new and challenging projects. A non-exhaustive (and quite random) list of projects and experiences in which I took part can be found below. Exploitation of research: technology & knowledge transfer: 5 days training on research valorisation by KU Leuven Research & Development (LRD), including sessions on intellectual property law, industry collaboration and exploitation plans and with a hands-on project on validation of research results.

item.title: Science Communication
item.description: Wetenschapsbattle / Battle of the Scientists: Science communication challenge: present your research to children age 6-12. I was selected of one of the five finalists and presented my work to an audience of 3500 children. (in dutch) [link] Science figured out: How to keep a secret?: 3 minute video presentation on the need for post-quantum cryptography and side-channel attacks for a broad audience (in dutch) [link]

item.title: Publications
item.description: Attacking and Defending Masked Polynomial Comparison for Lattice-Based Cryptography with Shivam Bhasin, Daniel Heinz, Thomas PÃ¶ppelmann and Michiel Van Beirendonck, Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2021/104 [eprint] Error Term Checking: Towards Chosen Ciphertext Security without Re-encryption with Emmanuela Orsini and Frederik Vercauteren, Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2021/080 [eprint] Analysis and Comparison of Table-based Arithmetic to Boolean Masking with Michiel Van Beirendonck, Ingrid Verbauwhede, Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2021/067 [eprint]

item.title: About me
item.description: I’m a PhD student in the COSIC research group at KU Leuven, Belgium under the supervision of Ingrid Verbauwhede and Frederik Vercauteren. I research the security and efficiency of post-quantum cryptography, with a focus on lattice-based cryptography. I’m involved in the development of the encryption algorithm Saber, which is one of the candidates for standardization in the NIST post-quantum standardization process. That was gobbledigook to me, now in human language?
